articles.headline: $80 Million for 6 Weeks for Cable Chief
articles.snippet: Robert D. Marcus will receive a severance payment that amounts to more than $1 million a day for the six weeks he ran Time Warner Cable before agreeing to sell.
articles.abstract: Robert D. Marcus will receive a severance payment that amounts to more than $1 million a day for the six weeks he ran Time Warner Cable before agreeing to sell.
articles.lead_paragraph: Updated, 8:55 p.m. | Robert D. Marcus became chief executive of Time Warner Cable at the start of the year. Less than two months later, he agreed to sell the company to its largest rival, Comcast, for $45 billion.

articles.headline: Koch Group, Spending Freely, Hones Attack on Government
articles.snippet: Americans for Prosperity, backed by the Koch brothers, is using a data-driven approach as it pursues its overarching goal of changing the way voters think about government.
articles.abstract: Americans for Prosperity, backed by the Koch brothers, is using a data-driven approach as it pursues its overarching goal of changing the way voters think about government.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Americans for Prosperity — the group backed by David H. and Charles G. Koch that has been pouring millions of dollars into competitive Senate races to the rising alarm of Democrats — was also among the politically active groups on the ground in this month’s special House election on Florida’s Gulf Coast.
articles.byline: By Carl Hulse and Ashley Parker

articles.headline: Wind Industry’s New Technologies Are Helping It Compete on Price
articles.snippet: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.
articles.abstract: With new technology, the industry has been able to produce more power at lower cost by capturing the faster winds that blow at higher elevations.
articles.lead_paragraph: The wind industry has gone to great lengths over the years to snap up the best properties for its farms, often looking to remote swaths of prairie or distant mountain ridges to maximize energy production and minimize community opposition.

articles.headline: Microsoft Software Leak Inquiry Raises Privacy Issues
articles.snippet: The company conducted an inquiry by reading through email and instant messages, which may violate its promise of privacy, highlighting the power technology companies have to snoop on their customers.
articles.abstract: The company conducted an inquiry by reading through email and instant messages, which may violate its promise of privacy, highlighting the power technology companies have to snoop on their customers.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Technology companies have spent months denying they know anything about broad government spying on people who use their Internet services.
articles.byline: By Nick Wingfield and Nick Bilton

articles.headline: ‘The Technology Is Out There,’ but Satellites Don’t Track Jets
articles.snippet: The airline industry has sophisticated tools to follow planes and stream data from their flight recorders. But given cost and the general safety of air travel, neither the airlines nor regulators have used them.
articles.abstract: The airline industry has sophisticated tools to follow planes and stream data from their flight recorders. But given cost and the general safety of air travel, neither the airlines nor regulators have used them.
articles.lead_paragraph: Airlines routinely use satellites to provide Wi-Fi for passengers. But for years they have failed to use a similar technology for a far more basic task: tracking planes and their black-box flight recorders.
articles.byline: By Jad Mouawad, Christopher Drew and Nicola Clark

articles.headline: Illusion of Safety at Afghan Haven Is Shattered
articles.snippet: A deadly attack by Taliban insurgents on a Kabul hotel favored by Westerners and the Afghan elite reinforced fears that the election to replace President Hamid Karzai will be accompanied by widening bloodshed.
articles.abstract: A deadly attack by Taliban insurgents on a Kabul hotel favored by Westerners and the Afghan elite reinforced fears that the election to replace President Hamid Karzai will be accompanied by widening bloodshed.
articles.lead_paragraph: KABUL, Afghanistan — His handgun drawn, the clean-cut insurgent stood in the restaurant of the Serena Hotel in Kabul, listening to the mother of three as she begged, “Take my life, but please don’t kill my kids.”
articles.byline: By Matthew Rosenberg and Azam Ahmed

articles.headline: After 58 Years in a Couple, a Spouse Fights for Benefits
articles.snippet: Some couples have been tripped up by bureaucratic rules concerning spousal benefits, despite the overturn last year of the federal law banning gay marriage.
articles.abstract: Some couples have been tripped up by bureaucratic rules concerning spousal benefits, despite the overturn last year of the federal law banning gay marriage.
articles.lead_paragraph: On Dec. 13, 1953, Lawrence Schacht walked into the Cork Club on West 72nd Street in Manhattan and spotted Russell Frink Jr. at the bar. From that moment forward, the two were inseparable.

articles.headline: Revelations of N.S.A. Spying Cost U.S. Tech Companies
articles.snippet: America’s cloud computing industry could lose billions of dollars in business because of the government’s surveillance program.
articles.abstract: America’s cloud computing industry could lose billions of dollars in business because of the government’s surveillance program.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Microsoft has lost customers, including the government of Brazil.

articles.headline: Students See Many Slights as Racial ‘Microaggressions’
articles.snippet: Blogs, papers and other projects have prompted wider discussion of “microaggressions,” remarks with a basis in racial, gender or other stereotypes.
articles.abstract: Blogs, papers and other projects have prompted wider discussion of “microaggressions,” remarks with a basis in racial, gender or other stereotypes.
articles.lead_paragraph: CAMBRIDGE, Mass. — A tone-deaf inquiry into an Asian-American’s ethnic origin. Cringe-inducing praise for how articulate a black student is. An unwanted conversation about a Latino’s ability to speak English without an accent.
